PHY_MAGN_E_001.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_E_001.question_text: A long straight wire carries a current of 10 A. Calculate the magnetic field at a perpendicular distance of 5 cm from the wire. (Take μ₀ = 4π × 10⁻⁷ T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_E_001.question_text_html: A long straight wire carries a current of 10 A. Calculate the magnetic field at a perpendicular distance of 5 cm from the wire. (Take μ₀ = 4π × 10-7 T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_E_001.solution_text: Using formula for magnetic field due to infinite straight wire: B = (μ₀I)/(2πr). Substituting: B = (4π × 10⁻⁷ × 10)/(2π × 0.05) = (4 × 10⁻⁶)/(0.1) = 4 × 10⁻⁵ T

solution_steps.explanation: For an infinitely long straight current-carrying conductor, the magnetic field at perpendicular distance r is given by Ampere's law result
Convert distance to meters: 5 cm = 0.05 m, then substitute I = 10 A

concepts_tested: Magnetic field due to straight conductor
PHY_MAGN_E_001.jee_pattern: Direct formula application for magnetic field

common_mistakes: Forgetting to convert cm to meters
Not canceling π in numerator and denominator
metadata.hint: Use Ampere's law result for infinite straight wire
metadata.key_insight: Tests basic application of magnetic field formula for straight conductor

PHY_MAGN_E_002.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_E_002.question_text: A conductor of length 20 cm carrying a current of 5 A is placed perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of 0.8 T. Calculate the force acting on the conductor.
PHY_MAGN_E_002.question_text_html: A conductor of length 20 cm carrying a current of 5 A is placed perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of 0.8 T. Calculate the force acting on the conductor.
PHY_MAGN_E_002.solution_text: Force on a current-carrying conductor: F = BIL sin θ. Since perpendicular, θ = 90°, so sin θ = 1. F = 0.8 × 5 × 0.20 × 1 = 0.8 N

solution_steps.description: Write the formula for force on current-carrying conductor
solution_steps.explanation: Force depends on magnetic field strength B, current I, length L, and angle θ between conductor and field

solution_steps.description: Identify that conductor is perpendicular to field
solution_steps.explanation: When conductor is perpendicular to magnetic field, maximum force occurs
Convert 20 cm = 0.20 m and substitute all values

concepts_tested: Force on conductor in magnetic field
PHY_MAGN_E_002.jee_pattern: Direct application of F = BIL formula

metadata.hint: When conductor is perpendicular to field, sin θ = 1
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of force on current-carrying conductor

PHY_MAGN_E_003.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_E_003.question_text: A circular coil of radius 10 cm carries a current of 2 A. What is the magnetic moment of the coil?
PHY_MAGN_E_003.question_text_html: A circular coil of radius 10 cm carries a current of 2 A. What is the magnetic moment of the coil?
PHY_MAGN_E_003.solution_text: Magnetic moment M = IA where A is area of loop. Area = πr² = π(0.1)² = 0.0314 m². Therefore M = 2 × 0.0314 = 0.0628 A·m²

solution_steps.explanation: Magnetic moment equals current times area enclosed by the loop
Convert radius to meters (10 cm = 0.1 m) and calculate area

common_mistakes: Not converting cm to m before calculating area
metadata.hint: First calculate the area of the circular coil
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of magnetic moment definition
metadata.elimination_strategy: Rough estimate: A ≈ 3 × (0.1)² ≈ 0.03, so M ≈ 2 × 0.03 ≈ 0.06. Eliminates B, C, D

distractor_analysis.B: Calculated area only, forgot to multiply by current (just πr²)
distractor_analysis.C: Calculation error - possibly used 2πr instead of πr², or other arithmetic mistake
distractor_analysis.D: Used diameter (0.2 m) as radius in area calculation: M = 2 × π(0.2)² = 0.2513 A·m²

PHY_MAGN_E_004.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_E_004.image_description: A rectangular current-carrying loop placed in a uniform magnetic field B. The loop has dimensions and current marked. Magnetic field lines shown horizontally. Loop makes angle with field direction.
PHY_MAGN_E_004.image_alt_text: Rectangular loop in magnetic field showing torque configuration
PHY_MAGN_E_004.diagram_code_python: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt; import numpy as np; from matplotlib.patches import Rectangle, FancyArrowPatch; fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(10, 7)); ax.set_xlim(-2, 8); ax.set_ylim(-2, 6); ax.set_aspect('equal'); ax.axis('off'); for y in np.arange(0, 5, 0.6): ax.arrow(0, y, 6, 0, head_width=0.15, head_length=0.2, fc='#6B46C1', ec='#6B46C1', linewidth=2); ax.text(6.5, 2, 'B', fontsize=18, color='#6B46C1', fontweight='bold'); rect_center = np.array([3.5, 2.5]); width, height = 2, 1.5; angle = 60; t = np.radians(angle); corners = np.array([[-width/2, -height/2], [width/2, -height/2], [width/2, height/2], [-width/2, height/2], [-width/2, -height/2]]); rot_matrix = np.array([[np.cos(t), -np.sin(t)], [np.sin(t), np.cos(t)]]); rot_corners = corners @ rot_matrix.T + rect_center; ax.plot(rot_corners[:, 0], rot_corners[:, 1], 'r-', linewidth=3); for i in range(4): mid = (rot_corners[i] + rot_corners[i+1]) / 2; if i % 2 == 0: ax.plot([mid[0]], [mid[1]], 'o', markersize=8, color='orange'); ax.text(-1, 2.5, '60°', fontsize=14, color='green', fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='#FDE68A', alpha=0.8)); ax.text(3.2, 1.2, 'I = 3 A', fontsize=12, color='red', fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='white', alpha=0.8)); ax.text(2.2, 4.2, 'Area = 0.02 m²', fontsize=12, color='blue', fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='white', alpha=0.8)); ax.set_title('Current Loop in Magnetic Field B = 0.5 T', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=15); plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig('output.svg', format='svg', bbox_inches='tight'); plt.close()
PHY_MAGN_E_004.question_text: A rectangular current-carrying loop of area 0.02 m² carrying a current of 3 A is placed in a uniform magnetic field of 0.5 T. The plane of the loop makes an angle of 60° with the direction of the magnetic field. Calculate the torque acting on the loop.
PHY_MAGN_E_004.question_text_html: A rectangular current-carrying loop of area 0.02 m² carrying a current of 3 A is placed in a uniform magnetic field of 0.5 T. The plane of the loop makes an angle of 60° with the direction of the magnetic field. Calculate the torque acting on the loop.
PHY_MAGN_E_004.solution_text: Torque τ = MB sin θ where M is magnetic moment. If plane makes 60° with field, angle between M and B is 90° - 60° = 30°. M = IA = 3 × 0.02 = 0.06 A·m². Therefore τ = 0.06 × 0.5 × sin 30° = 0.03 × 0.5 = 0.015 N·m

solution_steps.explanation: Magnetic moment M is perpendicular to the plane of loop. If plane makes 60° with B, then M makes 30° with B
Magnetic moment equals current times area
Torque on magnetic dipole in uniform field

metadata.formula_used: τ = MB sin θ, M = IA
common_mistakes: Not understanding that M is perpendicular to plane
metadata.hint: Remember magnetic moment is perpendicular to the plane of the loop
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of angle relationship between plane and magnetic moment

PHY_MAGN_E_005.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_E_005.question_text: An electron moving with a velocity of 2 × 10⁶ m/s enters perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of 0.3 T. Calculate the force acting on the electron. (Take charge of electron e = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C)
PHY_MAGN_E_005.question_text_html: An electron moving with a velocity of 2 × 106 m/s enters perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of 0.3 T. Calculate the force acting on the electron. (Take charge of electron e = 1.6 × 10-19 C)
PHY_MAGN_E_005.solution_text: Lorentz force: F = qvB sin θ. Since perpendicular motion, θ = 90°, sin θ = 1. F = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ × 2 × 10⁶ × 0.3 = 9.6 × 10⁻¹⁴ N

solution_steps.explanation: Force on a charged particle moving in a magnetic field
Electron enters perpendicular to field, so maximum force

metadata.key_insight: Tests Lorentz force application for charged particles

PHY_MAGN_E_006.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_E_006.question_text: A solenoid of length 50 cm has 500 turns and carries a current of 4 A. Calculate the magnetic field at the center of the solenoid. (Take μ₀ = 4π × 10⁻⁷ T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_E_006.question_text_html: A solenoid of length 50 cm has 500 turns and carries a current of 4 A. Calculate the magnetic field at the center of the solenoid. (Take μ₀ = 4π × 10-7 T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_E_006.solution_text: Magnetic field inside solenoid: B = μ₀nI where n is turns per unit length. n = 500/0.5 = 1000 turns/m. B = 4π × 10⁻⁷ × 1000 × 4 = 5.03 × 10⁻³ T

solution_steps.description: Write formula for solenoid magnetic field
solution_steps.explanation: For a long solenoid, field inside is uniform and given by this formula, where n is turn density
Convert length to meters (50 cm = 0.5 m) and find turns per meter

common_mistakes: Using N instead of n in formula
metadata.hint: First calculate turn density n = N/L
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of solenoid field formula

PHY_MAGN_E_007.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_E_007.image_description: A circular current-carrying loop viewed from the side, showing current direction and magnetic field at the center. Field lines emerging from center perpendicular to plane of loop.
PHY_MAGN_E_007.image_alt_text: Circular loop with current and magnetic field at center
PHY_MAGN_E_007.diagram_code_python: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt; import numpy as np; fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(9, 8)); ax.set_xlim(-3, 3); ax.set_ylim(-3, 3); ax.set_aspect('equal'); ax.axis('off'); theta = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 100); r = 2; x_circle = r * np.cos(theta); y_circle = r * np.sin(theta); ax.plot(x_circle, y_circle, linewidth=4, color='#6B46C1'); n_arrows = 8; for i in range(n_arrows): angle = 2*np.pi * i / n_arrows; x = r * np.cos(angle); y = r * np.sin(angle); dx = -r * np.sin(angle) * 0.3; dy = r * np.cos(angle) * 0.3; ax.arrow(x, y, dx, dy, head_width=0.2, head_length=0.15, fc='orange', ec='orange', linewidth=2); ax.plot([0], [0], 'ro', markersize=12, label='Center'); ax.arrow(0, 0, 0, 1.5, head_width=0.15, head_length=0.2, fc='#D946EF', ec='#D946EF', linewidth=3); ax.text(0.3, 1.2, 'B', fontsize=18, color='#D946EF', fontweight='bold'); ax.text(2.5, 0, 'I', fontsize=16, color='orange', fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='#FDE68A', alpha=0.8)); ax.text(-2.8, -2.5, 'r = 0.2 m', fontsize=12, color='blue', fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='white', alpha=0.8)); ax.text(-2.8, 2.5, 'I = 6 A', fontsize=12, color='green', fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='white', alpha=0.8)); ax.set_title('Magnetic Field at Center of Circular Loop', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=15); plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig('output.svg', format='svg', bbox_inches='tight'); plt.close()
PHY_MAGN_E_007.question_text: A circular loop of radius 0.2 m carries a current of 6 A as shown in the diagram. What is the magnitude of magnetic field at the center of the loop? (Take μ₀ = 4π × 10⁻⁷ T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_E_007.question_text_html: A circular loop of radius 0.2 m carries a current of 6 A as shown in the diagram. What is the magnitude of magnetic field at the center of the loop? (Take μ₀ = 4π × 10-7 T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_E_007.solution_text: Magnetic field at center of circular loop: B = (μ₀I)/(2r). Substituting: B = (4π × 10⁻⁷ × 6)/(2 × 0.2) = (24π × 10⁻⁷)/0.4 = 1.88 × 10⁻⁵ T

solution_steps.explanation: Magnetic field at the center of a circular current loop from Biot-Savart law
Insert given values of current and radius

concepts_tested: Magnetic field at center of loop
PHY_MAGN_E_007.jee_pattern: Field at center of circular loop

metadata.hint: Use the standard formula for field at center of circular loop
metadata.key_insight: Tests direct application of center field formula
metadata.elimination_strategy: Rough estimate: B ≈ (12 × 10⁻⁷ × 6)/0.4 ≈ 2 × 10⁻⁵. Closest is A

distractor_analysis.B: Forgot the factor of 2 in denominator (B = μ₀I/r instead of μ₀I/2r)
distractor_analysis.C: Used diameter d=0.4 m instead of radius r=0.2 m and forgot factor of 2, or major calculation error
distractor_analysis.D: Used diameter d=0.4 m as the radius value in the formula B = μ₀I/2r

PHY_MAGN_E_008.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_E_008.question_text: Two long parallel wires carrying currents of 5 A each in the same direction are placed 10 cm apart. Calculate the force per unit length on each wire. (Take μ₀ = 4π × 10⁻⁷ T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_E_008.question_text_html: Two long parallel wires carrying currents of 5 A each in the same direction are placed 10 cm apart. Calculate the force per unit length on each wire. (Take μ₀ = 4π × 10-7 T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_E_008.solution_text: Force per unit length between parallel conductors: F/L = (μ₀I₁I₂)/(2πd). Substituting: F/L = (4π × 10⁻⁷ × 5 × 5)/(2π × 0.1) = (100 × 10⁻⁷)/(0.2) = 5 × 10⁻⁵ N/m (attractive)

solution_steps.description: Write formula for force between parallel wires
solution_steps.explanation: Force per unit length between two parallel current-carrying conductors
Convert 10 cm = 0.1 m. Currents are equal: I₁ = I₂ = 5 A
Simplify (π cancels). Since currents are in same direction, force is attractive

metadata.hint: Same direction currents attract each other
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of force between parallel conductors

PHY_MAGN_E_009.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_E_009.question_text: A proton enters perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of 0.5 T. If the mass of proton is 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ kg and charge is 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, what is the cyclotron frequency?
PHY_MAGN_E_009.question_text_html: A proton enters perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of 0.5 T. If the mass of proton is 1.67 × 10-27 kg and charge is 1.6 × 10-19 C, what is the cyclotron frequency?
PHY_MAGN_E_009.solution_text: Cyclotron frequency: f = qB/(2πm). Substituting: f = (1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ × 0.5)/(2π × 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷) = (0.8 × 10⁻¹⁹)/(1.05 × 10⁻²⁶) ≈ 7.66 × 10⁶ Hz

solution_steps.explanation: For a charged particle in perpendicular magnetic field, frequency is independent of velocity
Insert given charge, magnetic field, and mass

metadata.hint: Cyclotron frequency is independent of particle velocity
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of charged particle circular motion
metadata.elimination_strategy: Order of magnitude: q/m ≈ 10⁸, B ≈ 0.5, so f ≈ 10⁸/6 ≈ 10⁷. Only A is close

distractor_analysis.D: Wrong power of 10 in final answer

PHY_MAGN_E_010.diagram_code_python: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt; import numpy as np; from matplotlib.patches import FancyArrowPatch; fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(10, 8)); ax.set_xlim(-1, 6); ax.set_ylim(-1, 5); ax.set_aspect('equal'); ax.axis('off'); ax.arrow(1, 1, 1.5, 0, head_width=0.15, head_length=0.15, fc='#6B46C1', ec='#6B46C1', linewidth=3); ax.text(1.7, 0.5, 'dl', fontsize=16, color='#6B46C1', fontweight='bold'); ax.text(0.5, 1.3, 'I', fontsize=14, color='blue', fontweight='bold'); ax.plot([2.5], [1], 'ro', markersize=10); ax.plot([5], [4], 'go', markersize=12); ax.text(5.2, 4, 'P', fontsize=16, color='green', fontweight='bold'); ax.plot([2.5, 5], [1, 4], 'k--', linewidth=2); ax.text(3.5, 2.8, 'r', fontsize=14, color='black', fontweight='bold'); arc = plt.Circle((2.5, 1), 0.8, fill=False, color='orange', linewidth=2); ax.add_patch(arc); ax.plot([2.5, 3.3], [1, 1], 'orange', linewidth=2); ax.plot([2.5, 3.0], [1, 1.6], 'orange', linewidth=2); ax.text(3.0, 1.3, 'θ', fontsize=14, color='orange', fontweight='bold'); ax.arrow(5, 4, 0, -0.8, head_width=0.15, head_length=0.15, fc='#D946EF', ec='#D946EF', linewidth=3); ax.text(5.3, 3.5, 'dB', fontsize=16, color='#D946EF', fontweight='bold'); ax.text(1, 4, 'Biot-Savart Law', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='#FDE68A', alpha=0.8)); ax.text(0.5, 3.3, r'dB ∝ (I·dl·sinθ)/r²', fontsize=12, bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='white', alpha=0.8)); ax.set_title('Magnetic Field due to Current Element', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=15); plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig('output.svg', format='svg', bbox_inches='tight'); plt.close()
PHY_MAGN_E_010.question_text: According to Biot-Savart law, the magnetic field dB at a point P due to a current element I·dl is proportional to sin θ/r², where θ is the angle between current element and line joining element to point P. At what angle θ is the magnetic field maximum?
PHY_MAGN_E_010.question_text_html: According to Biot-Savart law, the magnetic field dB at a point P due to a current element I·dl is proportional to sin θ/r², where θ is the angle between current element and line joining element to point P. At what angle θ is the magnetic field maximum?
PHY_MAGN_E_010.solution_text: From Biot-Savart law: dB ∝ sin θ. For maximum field, sin θ should be maximum. Since maximum value of sin θ = 1 when θ = 90°, the magnetic field is maximum when θ = 90°.

solution_steps.explanation: Magnetic field depends on sin θ among other factors
Sine function has maximum value of 1
This occurs when current element is perpendicular to the line joining it to point P

common_mistakes: Confusing with angle for minimum field
metadata.key_insight: Tests understanding of Biot-Savart law angular dependence

PHY_MAGN_M_025.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_M_025.question_text: A coil of 50 turns, area 100 cm², current 2 A in B=0.2T. Torque is 0.1 N·m. Find angle between magnetic moment and field.
PHY_MAGN_M_025.question_text_html: A coil of 50 turns, area 100 cm², current 2 A in B=0.2T. Torque is 0.1 N·m. Find angle between magnetic moment and field.
PHY_MAGN_M_025.solution_text: τ = NIAB sin θ. M = NIA = 50×2×0.01 = 1 A·m². 0.1 = 1×0.2×sin θ. sin θ = 0.5, so θ = 30°

solution_steps.formula: τ = MB sin θ = NIAB sin θ
solution_steps.explanation: Torque on coil in B field

PHY_MAGN_M_027.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_M_027.question_text: A horizontal wire of length 1m carries 5A in B=0.8T perpendicular downward. What mass must be added to balance? (g=10 m/s²)
PHY_MAGN_M_027.question_text_html: A horizontal wire of length 1m carries 5A in B=0.8T perpendicular downward. What mass must be added to balance? (g=10 m/s²)
PHY_MAGN_M_027.solution_text: F_mag = BIL = 0.8×5×1 = 4N upward. To balance: mg = 4, so m = 4/10 = 0.4 kg

PHY_MAGN_M_028.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_M_028.question_text: Electron (v=2×10⁶ m/s) enters E=1000V/m region perpendicular, travels 5cm before exiting. What perpendicular B deflects it equally?
PHY_MAGN_M_028.question_text_html: Electron (v=2×106 m/s) enters E=1000V/m region perpendicular, travels 5cm before exiting. What perpendicular B deflects it equally?
PHY_MAGN_M_028.solution_text: For equal deflection: qE/(mv²) = qBv/(mv²), simplifies to E = Bv². Wait, incorrect. Equal deflection means equal acceleration or equal radius. For perpendicular fields: B = E/v. B = 1000/(2×10⁶) = 5×10⁻⁴ T

PHY_MAGN_M_029.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_M_029.question_text: Two coaxial circular coils of same radius 10cm, 100 turns each, 10cm apart carry 2A in same direction. Field at midpoint?
PHY_MAGN_M_029.question_text_html: Two coaxial circular coils of same radius 10cm, 100 turns each, 10cm apart carry 2A in same direction. Field at midpoint?
PHY_MAGN_M_029.solution_text: Each coil at x=5cm from midpoint. B_each = (μ₀NIr²)/(2(r²+x²)^(3/2)). Same direction → add. B_total = 2×B_each ≈ 3.58×10⁻³ T

PHY_MAGN_M_030.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_M_030.question_text: A proton moves in a uniform magnetic field. What work does the magnetic force do on the proton?
PHY_MAGN_M_030.question_text_html: A proton moves in a uniform magnetic field. What work does the magnetic force do on the proton?
PHY_MAGN_M_030.solution_text: Magnetic force F = qv×B is always perpendicular to velocity. W = F·ds = 0 since F ⊥ v always. Magnetic force does no work.

solution_steps.explanation: Cross product → F perpendicular to v

metadata.hint: Magnetic force always perpendicular to motion
metadata.elimination_strategy: Speed doesn't change in B field

distractor_analysis.B: Confused with electric force doing work

PHY_MAGN_MH_033.image_description: Square loop of side a carrying current I, showing field at center from all 4 sides using Biot-Savart
PHY_MAGN_MH_033.diagram_code_python: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt; import numpy as np; fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10,8)); ax.set_xlim(-3,3); ax.set_ylim(-3,3); ax.set_aspect('equal'); ax.axis('off'); square = np.array([[-1.5,-1.5],[-1.5,1.5],[1.5,1.5],[1.5,-1.5],[-1.5,-1.5]]); ax.plot(square[:,0], square[:,1], lw=4, color='#6B46C1'); for i in range(4): mid = (square[i] + square[i+1])/2; if i == 0: ax.arrow(mid[0]-0.3, mid[1], 0.6, 0, head_width=0.15, head_length=0.1, fc='orange', ec='orange', lw=2); elif i == 1: ax.arrow(mid[0], mid[1]-0.3, 0, 0.6, head_width=0.15, head_length=0.1, fc='orange', ec='orange', lw=2); elif i == 2: ax.arrow(mid[0]+0.3, mid[1], -0.6, 0, head_width=0.15, head_length=0.1, fc='orange', ec='orange', lw=2); else: ax.arrow(mid[0], mid[1]+0.3, 0, -0.6, head_width=0.15, head_length=0.1, fc='orange', ec='orange', lw=2); ax.plot([0],[0], 'ro', ms=12); ax.text(0.2,-0.3, 'O', fontsize=14, color='red', weight='bold'); ax.plot([0,0.75],[0,0], 'g--', lw=2); ax.text(0.3,-0.5, 'a/2', fontsize=12, color='green', weight='bold'); ax.plot([0,0],[0,-1.5], 'b--', lw=1); ax.text(-0.4,-0.75, 'a/2', fontsize=12, color='blue', weight='bold'); ax.text(-2.5,2.5, 'a=20cm', fontsize=12, weight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round',fc='#FDE68A')); ax.text(-2.5,2.0, 'I=10A', fontsize=12, weight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round',fc='white')); ax.plot([0],[0], 'x', ms=20, color='#D946EF', mew=3); ax.text(0.4,0.4, 'B(⊗)', fontsize=14, color='#D946EF', weight='bold'); ax.set_title('Square Loop Field at Center', fontsize=14, weight='bold'); plt.tight_layout(); plt.savefig('output.svg', format='svg', bbox_inches='tight'); plt.close()
PHY_MAGN_MH_033.question_text: A square loop of side 20 cm carries current 10 A. Calculate magnetic field at the center. (μ₀ = 4π×10⁻⁷ T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_MH_033.question_text_html: A square loop of side 20 cm carries current 10 A. Calculate magnetic field at the center. (μ₀ = 4π×10-7 T·m/A)
PHY_MAGN_MH_033.solution_text: Each side contributes B_side = (μ₀I√2)/(πa). Four sides: B = (4μ₀I√2)/(πa) = (4×1.414×4π×10⁻⁷×10)/(π×0.2) = 11.32×10⁻⁵ T

solution_steps.explanation: Each side at perpendicular distance a/2

PHY_MAGN_MH_033.validation_notes: Fixed formula factor of 2 per Gemini

metadata.hint: Each side is like finite wire at perpendicular distance a/2

PHY_MAGN_MH_034.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_MH_034.question_text: A charged particle is accelerated through potential difference V and enters perpendicular to magnetic field B. If V is doubled, the cyclotron frequency:
PHY_MAGN_MH_034.question_text_html: A charged particle is accelerated through potential difference V and enters perpendicular to magnetic field B. If V is doubled, the cyclotron frequency:
PHY_MAGN_MH_034.solution_text: Cyclotron frequency f = qB/(2πm) depends only on q, B, and m. It is independent of velocity or kinetic energy. Even though doubling V increases v by √2, frequency remains unchanged.

solution_steps.explanation: Frequency depends on charge-to-mass ratio and field
Velocity changes with V, but frequency formula has no v
f unchanged even if V doubled

metadata.elimination_strategy: f has no v term in formula

distractor_analysis.D: Confused with energy or KE change

PHY_MAGN_MH_036.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_MH_036.question_text: A proton moving at 10⁶ m/s enters a uniform B=0.5T field at 60° to the field lines. Find minimum distance from entry point during motion. (m_p=1.67×10⁻²⁷kg, q=1.6×10⁻¹⁹C)
PHY_MAGN_MH_036.question_text_html: A proton moving at 106 m/s enters a uniform B=0.5T field at 60° to the field lines. Find minimum distance from entry point during motion. (m_p=1.67×10-27kg, q=1.6×10-19C)
PHY_MAGN_MH_036.solution_text: Helical motion. v_perp = v sin 60° = 10⁶ × 0.866 = 8.66×10⁵ m/s. Radius r = mv_perp/(qB) = (1.67×10⁻²⁷ × 8.66×10⁵)/(1.6×10⁻¹⁹ × 0.5) = 1.81×10⁻² m. Minimum distance = 2r = 3.62 cm

solution_steps.explanation: Only perpendicular component creates circular motion
Circular motion in plane perpendicular to B

common_mistakes: Using total v instead of v_⊥
metadata.hint: Minimum distance is diameter of circular component

PHY_MAGN_MH_037.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_MH_037.question_text: A horizontal wire of mass 10 g/m levitates in Earth's horizontal B=4×10⁻⁵T field. Minimum current needed is (g=10 m/s²):
PHY_MAGN_MH_037.question_text_html: A horizontal wire of mass 10 g/m levitates in Earth's horizontal B=4×10-5T field. Minimum current needed is (g=10 m/s²):
PHY_MAGN_MH_037.solution_text: For levitation: BIL = mg. Per unit length: BI = (m/L)g = λg. I = λg/B = (0.01 × 10)/(4×10⁻⁵) = 0.1/(4×10⁻⁵) = 2500 A

metadata.hint: Current perpendicular to both B and g
metadata.key_insight: Large current needed for weak field
metadata.elimination_strategy: Order of magnitude: mg/L ∼ 0.1, B ∼ 10⁻⁵, so I ∼ 10³-10⁴

PHY_MAGN_MH_038.question_text: An infinite sheet carries surface current density K=5 A/m perpendicular to the plane. Calculate magnetic field on either side. (μ₀=4π×10⁻⁷)
PHY_MAGN_MH_038.question_text_html: An infinite sheet carries surface current density K=5 A/m perpendicular to the plane. Calculate magnetic field on either side. (μ₀=4π×10-7)
PHY_MAGN_MH_038.solution_text: For infinite current sheet: B = μ₀K/2 on each side. B = (4π×10⁻⁷ × 5)/2 = 10π×10⁻⁷ = 3.14×10⁻⁶ T. Field parallel to sheet, perpendicular to current.

solution_steps.explanation: From Ampere's law for infinite sheet

metadata.hint: Field independent of distance from sheet

PHY_MAGN_MH_039.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_MH_039.question_text: A circular loop of radius 10 cm, 50 turns, current 3 A in B=0.8T is rotated from θ=0° to θ=90° (angle between normal and B). Work done by external agent?
PHY_MAGN_MH_039.question_text_html: A circular loop of radius 10 cm, 50 turns, current 3 A in B=0.8T is rotated from θ=0° to θ=90° (angle between normal and B). Work done by external agent?
PHY_MAGN_MH_039.solution_text: Work = change in potential energy = U_final - U_initial = -MB cos 90° - (-MB cos 0°) = MB. M = NIA = 50 × 3 × π(0.1)² = 4.712 A·m². W = 4.712 × 0.8 = 3.77 J

metadata.formula_used: W = ΔU = MB(cos θ_i - cos θ_f)
metadata.hint: Work = change in magnetic potential energy

PHY_MAGN_MH_040.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_MH_040.question_text: A velocity selector with E=3×10⁴V/m, B=0.6T allows particles with specific v to pass. If a singly ionized ion and doubly ionized ion both pass through, their mass ratio m₁/m₂ is:
PHY_MAGN_MH_040.question_text_html: A velocity selector with E=3×104V/m, B=0.6T allows particles with specific v to pass. If a singly ionized ion and doubly ionized ion both pass through, their mass ratio m₁/m₂ is:
PHY_MAGN_MH_040.solution_text: Velocity selector condition: v = E/B is independent of charge and mass. Both ions have same selected velocity v = 3×10⁴/0.6 = 5×10⁴ m/s regardless of their masses. Mass ratio cannot be determined from velocity selector alone.

solution_steps.explanation: Both ions pass → both have this v
v = E/B has no mass term

metadata.hint: Velocity selector independent of q and m
metadata.key_insight: All particles with same v pass
metadata.elimination_strategy: v = E/B has no q or m

distractor_analysis.A: Incorrectly thought masses must be equal

PHY_MAGN_MH_041.question_text: A wire is bent into semicircle of radius 10 cm with two straight radial sections. Current 12 A flows through. Find field at center O. (μ₀=4π×10⁻⁷)
PHY_MAGN_MH_041.question_text_html: A wire is bent into semicircle of radius 10 cm with two straight radial sections. Current 12 A flows through. Find field at center O. (μ₀=4π×10-7)
PHY_MAGN_MH_041.solution_text: Semicircle contributes B_semi = μ₀I/(4R). Radial sections contribute zero (current along radius). B_total = μ₀I/(4R) = (4π×10⁻⁷ × 12)/(4 × 0.1) = 12π×10⁻⁷/0.4 = 3.77×10⁻⁵ T

solution_steps.explanation: Current radial from center → no field at center

metadata.hint: Radial currents produce zero field at center

PHY_MAGN_MH_043.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_MH_043.question_text: A coaxial cable has inner conductor (radius a) carrying current I and outer conductor (radius b) carrying return current -I. Magnetic field at distance r where a < r < b is:
PHY_MAGN_MH_043.question_text_html: A coaxial cable has inner conductor (radius a) carrying current I and outer conductor (radius b) carrying return current -I. Magnetic field at distance r where a < r < b is:
PHY_MAGN_MH_043.solution_text: Between conductors (a < r < b): Amperian loop encloses only inner current I. By Ampere's law: B(2πr) = μ₀I, so B = μ₀I/(2πr). Outer conductor doesn't contribute to field in this region.

solution_steps.explanation: Amperian loop at r encloses inner conductor

metadata.elimination_strategy: Only inner I enclosed → standard formula

PHY_MAGN_H_044.question_text: A conducting rod of length 0.4 m moves at 5 m/s perpendicular to rails in B=0.8T (perpendicular to plane). If circuit resistance is 2Ω, find power dissipated.
PHY_MAGN_H_044.question_text_html: A conducting rod of length 0.4 m moves at 5 m/s perpendicular to rails in B=0.8T (perpendicular to plane). If circuit resistance is 2Ω, find power dissipated.
PHY_MAGN_H_044.solution_text: EMF: ε = Bℓv = 0.8×0.4×5 = 1.6 V. Current I = ε/R = 0.8 A. Power P = I²R = 0.64×2 = 1.28 W OR P = ε²/R = 2.56/2 = 1.28 W
PHY_MAGN_H_044.validation_notes: Fixed P = ε²/R calculation per Gemini

metadata.hint: EMF = Bℓv, then use power formula

PHY_MAGN_H_045.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_H_045.question_text: A long solid cylinder of radius R carries uniform current I. The magnetic field inside at distance r from axis (r<R) varies as:
PHY_MAGN_H_045.question_text_html: A long solid cylinder of radius R carries uniform current I. The magnetic field inside at distance r from axis (r) varies as:
PHY_MAGN_H_045.solution_text: Apply Ampere's law to circular path at radius r < R. Current density J = I/(πR²). Enclosed current I_enc = J × πr² = I(r²/R²). By Ampere's law: B(2πr) = μ₀I(r²/R²), so B = (μ₀Ir)/(2πR²) ∝ r

metadata.hint: Inside: I_enc ∝ r², but B×r ∝ I_enc
metadata.elimination_strategy: At r=0, B=0; at r=R, B=max → must increase

distractor_analysis.C: Confused I_enc variation with B variation

PHY_MAGN_H_046.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_H_046.question_text: A proton accelerated through 1000V enters region 1 (B₁=0.5T) perpendicular, makes semicircle, then enters region 2 (B₂=1.0T) tangentially. Find ratio of radii r₁/r₂.
PHY_MAGN_H_046.question_text_html: A proton accelerated through 1000V enters region 1 (B₁=0.5T) perpendicular, makes semicircle, then enters region 2 (B₂=1.0T) tangentially. Find ratio of radii r₁/r₂.
PHY_MAGN_H_046.solution_text: Velocity same in both regions (magnetic force does no work). r = mv/(qB), so r₁/r₂ = B₂/B₁ = 1.0/0.5 = 2.0

solution_steps.explanation: Velocity determined by accelerating voltage, unchanged by B fields

metadata.key_insight: Ratio depends only on B fields

PHY_MAGN_H_047.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_H_047.question_text: Two long parallel wires separated by 10 cm carry 5A and 10A in same direction. At what distance from 5A wire (between them) is the net field zero?
PHY_MAGN_H_047.question_text_html: Two long parallel wires separated by 10 cm carry 5A and 10A in same direction. At what distance from 5A wire (between them) is the net field zero?
PHY_MAGN_H_047.solution_text: Between wires, fields oppose. Let 5A at x=0, 10A at x=10cm. At null point x from 5A: B₁ = B₂ → 5/x = 10/(10-x). Cross multiply: 50-5x = 10x → 50 = 15x → x = 10/3 = 3.33 cm from 5A wire

solution_steps.explanation: Same direction currents: fields oppose between. Place 5A at origin
Equal field magnitudes at null point distance x from 5A

metadata.key_insight: Null point closer to weaker current
metadata.elimination_strategy: Must be closer to 5A (weaker), so <5cm. Only A fits

PHY_MAGN_H_048.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_H_048.question_text: A bar magnet of moment M=2 A·m², moment of inertia I=0.01 kg·m² oscillates in B=0.5T. Find period of small oscillations.
PHY_MAGN_H_048.question_text_html: A bar magnet of moment M=2 A·m², moment of inertia I=0.01 kg·m² oscillates in B=0.5T. Find period of small oscillations.
PHY_MAGN_H_048.solution_text: Torque τ = -MB sin θ ≈ -MBθ for small θ. Equation: Iα = -MBθ. SHM with ω² = MB/I. Period T = 2π√(I/MB) = 2π√(0.01/(2×0.5)) = 2π√0.01 = 0.628 s

PHY_MAGN_H_049.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_H_049.question_text: A copper strip (width 2cm, thickness 0.1mm) carries 20A in B=1.2T perpendicular. Hall voltage is 0.6μV. Calculate drift velocity of electrons.
PHY_MAGN_H_049.question_text_html: A copper strip (width 2cm, thickness 0.1mm) carries 20A in B=1.2T perpendicular. Hall voltage is 0.6μV. Calculate drift velocity of electrons.
PHY_MAGN_H_049.solution_text: Hall voltage V_H = Bvd, where d = width = 0.02m. v = V_H/(Bd) = (0.6×10⁻⁶)/(1.2 × 0.02) = 6×10⁻⁷/0.024 = 2.5×10⁻⁵ m/s. Wait, let me recalculate: v = 0.6×10⁻⁶/(1.2×0.02) = 5×10⁻⁴ m/s = 0.5 mm/s

solution_steps.explanation: d is width between Hall electrodes
Actually: 6×10⁻⁷/2.4×10⁻² = 2.5×10⁻⁵ m/s = 0.025 mm/s. Need to verify

metadata.hint: Width is distance across Hall voltage

PHY_MAGN_H_050.subject: Physics
PHY_MAGN_H_050.question_text: A particle enters uniform B field with velocity components v_parallel and v_perp to B. The pitch of helical path equals 2π times the radius. Find v_parallel/v_perp.
PHY_MAGN_H_050.question_text_html: A particle enters uniform B field with velocity components v∥ and v⊥ to B. The pitch of helical path equals 2π times the radius. Find v∥/v⊥.
PHY_MAGN_H_050.solution_text: Pitch p = v_∥(2πm)/(qB), radius r = mv_⊥/(qB). Ratio p/r = 2πv_∥/v_⊥. Given p = 2πr, so p/r = 2π. Therefore 2πv_∥/v_⊥ = 2π, giving v_∥/v_⊥ = 1
PHY_MAGN_H_050.validation_notes: Rewrote: given p/r=2π, find v_∥/v_⊥=1 per Gemini
